I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has requested technical 
assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in reforming policies and developing 
plans to improve rural transport services to supplement the ongoing rural roads development 
program. The TA1 is included in ADB’s country strategy and program update (2006–2008),2 and 
was confirmed by the Government during ADB’s 2006 Country Programming Mission. The Fact-
Finding Mission (the Mission) was undertaken in March 2006 to formulate the TA. The Mission 
reached agreement with the Government on the TA objectives, scope, cost estimate, financing 
plan,  implementation  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The  country’s  sustained  economic  growth  over  the  last  two  decades  has  been 
accompanied  by  a  large  demand  for  transport.  This has resulted  in rapid  development  of 
transport infrastructure, and particularly of roads. During 1990 to 2005, the road traffic grew by 
9% for passenger reaching 929 billion passenger-kilometer, and 6% for freight reaching 869 
billion ton-km. According to the Ministry of Communications (MOC), the road network expanded 
to about 1.93 million km in 2005.3 Rural roads include county and township roads (which are 
included in the above network), as well as a large number of village roads.4 The estimate for 
rural roads vary between 1.5 million km to 3.0 million km.      
 
3.  The Government is focusing on rural development in an effort to reduce poverty, which 
is more prevalent in rural areas. Development in rural areas will help bridge the rural–urban 
divide, and create employment opportunities that will assist in curbing migration and controlling 
rapid urbanization.5 As part of this effort, the Government has specifically allocated resources 
for rural roads, as they play a significant role in fostering social and economic integration of the 
country and reducing poverty. By connecting rural areas to the existing road network, rural 
roads raise the productivity of poor households, help diversify income sources, and facilitate 
access to social services. Accordingly, MOC has prepared a multi-stage national rural road 
development program, involving construction and improvement of rural roads and expansion of 
transport services. The Government’s 11th five-year plan (FYP), 2006–2010, calls for linking the 
paved road network with (i) all townships and villages in the eastern region, (ii) all townships 
and 88% of villages in the central region, and (iii) 90% townships and 50% villages in the 
western region. The Government estimates that 2.4 million km of rural roads will be constructed 
or improved to achieve these targets. The Government plans to invest about CNY140 billion, 
and will seek additional financing from other sources.      
 
4.  The Government realizes that the benefits of improving rural roads will not be realized 
unless  road  transport  services  are  also  improved.  At  present,  the  capacity  and  quality  of 
transport services in rural areas is very low. Provision of reliable, efficient, and affordable 
transport services is crucial for improvement of rural economic conditions. Efficient transport 
services will allow the rural population to access competitive markets, as well as needed health,

2 
education, and other social services. Consequently, under the 11th FYP the Government gives 
priority  to  the  development  of  rural  transport  services  along  with  rural  road  infrastructure 
development. This includes improvement of bus and truck terminals, for which the Government 
plans to provide subsidies to provincial and local governments.6  
 
5.  ADB has financed two specific studies to improve road transport in the PRC.7 The first 
study, conducted in 1994, (i) assessed the structure, operations, and financial performance of 
state-owned and private passenger and freight transport; (ii) identified the characteristics that 
constrain  the  efficiency  of  the  road  transport  industry;  and  (iii)  recommended  options  for 
effective  market-oriented  operations.  The  recommendations  were  selectively  taken  up  in 
subsequent  road  subsector  projects.  The  second  study,  completed  in  2005,  focused  on 
formulating  and  implementing  policy  reforms  in  the  freight  and  passenger  road  transport 
industries. This study identified critical issues in the subsector’s (i) structure and performance, 
(ii) policies and plans for development, and (iii) governing institutions and regulatory framework. 
Based on the impact of policy, regulatory measures in three provinces, and lessons from other 
countries,  the  study  proposed  an  action  plan  for  policy  reforms.  Some  of  the  study’s 
recommendations are included in a project preparatory technical assistance and proposed road 
sector loan.8 These studies also provide some useful insight to the issue of road transport in 
rural areas.  
 
6.  Road transport services are regulated by provincial communication departments (PCDs) 
under MOC’s policy and guidelines. The PCDs issue licenses to transport operators, trucks, 
buses, drivers, and intercity bus services through their transport administration bureaus (TABs). 
County and township communication bureaus (CBs) are responsible for lower-level networks. 
Passenger buses are classified in three categories according to size (or seating capacity) and 
level  of  service  provided.  To  be  eligible  for  a  license,  bus  operators  must  meet  basic 
requirements for vehicle ownership, driver’s qualifications, and management capability. Routes 
are categorized in four classes based on the population centers they serve. Provincial TABs 
provide licenses for interprovincial bus routes, while lower-level routes are licensed by county 
CBs. Passenger fares are regulated by MOC, which issues annual national fare guidelines. 
Fares are established by PCDs and CBs based on these guidelines. For freight transport, the 
trucks are categorized in four classes based on their carrying capacity. Operators must meet 
basic  financial  resource  and  maintenance  capacity  requirements  to  obtain  a  license.  The 
vehicles  are  inspected  annually.  There  is  no  restriction  on  freight  transport  tariffs.  Both 
passenger and  freight  transport  services  are  provided  by  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs), 
foreign joint ventures, privately owned companies, and small operators. While the private sector 
is more closely involved in freight transport, passenger transport, particularly in rural areas, is 
dominated by provincial or municipal SOEs.  
   
7.  Transport services in rural areas are inadequate. Due to low demand, short journeys, 
and the limited ability of rural passengers to pay for transport, the services are unprofitable and 
do not attract investment. The existing regulatory framework does not encourage or provide

incentives to operators to improve services in rural areas. Consequently, services are infrequent 
and of poor quality. Some rural transport services are provided by CBs and SOEs who cover the 
losses through subsidies from profitable routes. There are also some government subsidies for 
rural services, but these are limited to infrastructure such as bus stops. Several county CBs 
charge lower fees and taxes to bus operators in areas where services are not profitable. These 
concessions are in the form of reduced transport management fees and passenger charges. 
 
8.  Bus service quality varies, with villages or townships near main highways benefiting from 
better  service,  while  remotely  located  population  centers  lack  quality  bus  service.  Remote 
villages  are  served  by  informal  transport  operators,  typically  through  motor  tricycles,  dual-
purpose trucks (carrying freight as well as passengers), and baby taxis (microbuses with seven 
seats). These vehicles are the only available means of transport in most townships and villages 
with very poor road conditions, as the authorities will not issue licenses to bus operators for 
safety reasons.     
 
9.  The current regulatory restrictions on bus route capacity and bus/terminal fares is an 
impediment to (i) maximizing vehicle utilization, (ii) increasing bus operating efficiency, and 
(iii) reducing  cost  through  more  flexible  market  competition.  The  role  of  road  transport 
administrations, which need to focus on monitoring the operations of the market and enforcing 
public safety and environmental regulations, should also be reviewed. 
 
10.  Provincial and municipal road transport administrations also control the development 
and operation of bus and truck terminals. Passenger and freight transport terminals or stations 
are  classified  in  four  categories  based  on  capacity,  land  area,  facilities,  and  equipment. 
Development of class I–II transport terminals is usually planned by provincial TABs, while others 
are generally planned by prefecture and county CBs, with approval of the provincial TAB. The 
terminals  are  normally  operated  as  public  facilities  by  SOEs  that  serve  bus  and  truck 
companies.  To  ensure  fair  competition,  terminal  operators  are  distinct  from  bus  and  truck 
operators.  Terminal  operators  are  responsible  for  regulating  bus  departure  schedules  and 
ensuring vehicle safety; bus terminal fares are regulated by the provincial authorities. 
 
11.  The  terminals’  lack  of  needed  infrastructure,  limited  capacity  and  low-level  facilities 
impede the growth of improved bus and truck services. Many freight transport stations/centers 
are simply parking places, and many townships and villages lack bus stations/stops. Both high-
level transport centers and base-level town bus stations and village bus stops are needed in 
order to closely connect urban and rural areas through an integrated transport service network, 
in  keeping  with  the  road  network  improvements.  In  rural  townships  and  villages,  bus 
stations/stops that provides a comfortable and safe passenger environment are lacking. Instead, 
random roadside areas or temporary areas in the township center are used as makeshift bus 
stops. This is both inefficient and unsafe, causing traffic blockages and road safety issues. The 
problem is exacerbated if the road passes through a crowded street market in the center of a 
township. 
 
12.  The provincial TAB sets general layout standards for and subsidizes half the cost of the 
construction  of  township  stations  and  village  stops,  with  local  CBs  responsible  for  their 
development. The standards are useful to ensure required facilities are provided and budgets 
controlled, but the standards are too restrictive, as route requirements vary significantly. Some 
existing township bus stations are not fully utilized, because of high terminal fees and low 
passenger flows that make transport services unviable. Although land-use planning and design 
standards are important, the dominant role played by local governments means that terminals 
are  not  developed  from  the  point  of  view  of  road  transport  users  and  suppliers.  Modern

4 
freight/logistics terminals equipped with information technology are lacking in most provinces, 
resulting in cargo damage, longer lead times for trucks, additional shifting of cargo, and reduced 
efficiency. 
 
13.  Development  of  rural  areas  requires  a  seamless  and  integrated  transport  services 
network, which connects urban and rural areas through high-level transport terminals in major 
cities and base-level bus stations/stops in townships and villages.    
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
14.  The TA will contribute to the Government’s objective of balanced and sustainable rural 
economic growth. The TA will help the Government provide reliable, efficient and safe transport 
to  the  rural  population  under  the  11th  FYP,  by  assisting  in  the  reform  of  policies  and 
development of plans for improvement of rural transport services to supplement the rural roads 
development program. This will be achieved by (i) undertaking a detailed assessment of rural 
transport, in particular transport operators, terminals, vehicles and routes; (ii) identifying priority 
rural transport projects to be implemented under the 11th FYP, in line with the Government’s 
objectives; (iii) recommending policy reforms for improvement of rural transport services; and 
(iv) developing the Government’s capacity to plan and implement rural transport improvements. 
The TA will assist the Government in planning and providing financing for improvement of 
transport services in rural areas.        
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  International consultants, supported by domestic consultants, will be engaged to help the 
Government improve rural transport services. The proposed TA will be undertaken in close 
consultation with the national and local governments and will take into consideration previous 
studies carried out by the Government, ADB, and other multilateral agencies. The TA will 
involve  analytical  research,  field  work,  training,  and  consultations  with  the  Government, 
provincial governments, and local stakeholders. The TA will be based on case studies in three 
provinces, selected from eastern, western, and central regions.9         
 
16.  Key activities under the proposed TA include (i) a detailed assessment of transport 
services in rural areas; (ii) recommendations on reforming the policy and regulatory framework 
to improve licensing and tariff setting; (iii) development of (a) incentives for transport operators 
to extend services to rural areas; (b) prioritized plans for development of transport terminals, 
stations,  and  stops  in  rural  areas  under  the  11th  FYP;  and  (c)  sustainable  measures  for 
operation  of  transport  terminals  in  rural  areas;  (iv)  capacity  development  of  institutions 
responsible for rural transport; (v) drafting of measures relating to transport service safety; and 
(vi) assessment of financing needs to improve and expand rural transport services.      
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000. The Government requested ADB to 
finance $400,000 equivalent, to cover the entire foreign exchange cost and $186,000 equivalent 
of the local currency cost. The TA is proposed to be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding program. The Government will finance the remaining $100,000 equivalent, which will be

5 
used to cover office accommodation and other facilities and services required to implement the 
TA. The details of the cost estimate and financing plan are in Appendix 1.    
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The TA will require about 23 person-months of consulting services (7 international and 
16 domestic) spread over a period of 6 months, including field work. The consultants will be 
engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the selection and engagement of domestic consultants. A 
team  of  international  consultants,  in  association  with  domestic  consulting  firm(s),  will  be 
engaged following the quality- and cost-based selection method, using biodata proposals. Two 
international consultants will provide expertise in rural transport (i) planning and operations; and 
(ii) policy, regulatory frameworks, and financing. One of the international consultants will be the 
team leader. In addition, six domestic consultants will provide expertise with respect to the 
following aspects of rural transport services: (i) planning and operations; (ii) policy, regulatory 
frameworks, and financing; (iii) transport terminals; (iv) vehicle operations and maintenance; (v) 
social development; and (vi) management and capacity development. Appendix 2 presents the 
outline terms of reference for consulting services.            
 
19.  MOC will be the Executing Agency and will be responsible for guiding and supervising 
TA activities, and for coordination with relevant Government agencies, and provincial and local 
governments. The TA is expected to begin in October 2006 and is scheduled to be completed 
by April 2007. The consultants will identify, provide logistical support for, and monitor the 
overseas training programs. MOC will provide the consultants with all relevant materials, recent 
studies, and reports required for the TA. The consultants will maintain close contact with MOC 
and ADB and will keep them informed of the TA progress and findings. Tripartite meetings 
involving the Government, ADB staff, and the consultants will be held in the PRC to review 
reports  and  provide  guidance.  The  consultants  will  procure  equipment  under  the  TA  in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2006). 
 
20.  The consultants will submit the following reports to ADB and MOC: (i) inception report, 4 
weeks following commencement of services; (ii) interim report, 10 weeks after commencement; 
(iii) draft final report, within 21 weeks of commencement; and (iv) final report, 2 weeks after 
receiving all comments from MOC and ADB. The consultants will hold stakeholder consultation 
workshops in the three selected provinces within 10 weeks of commencement of the services, 
and a final national workshop in Beijing to disseminate the TA findings within 4 weeks of 
submission of the draft final report. Each report will be submitted in English and Chinese to the 
Ministry of Finance, National Development Reform Commission, and MOC. Only the English 
version of the report will be submitted to ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Sustainable Rural Transport Services, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
1.  The consultants will review policies relating to and assess operations of rural road 
passenger and freight transport services, and prepare plans and policy reforms to assist the 
Government in improving rural transport under the 11th five-year plan (FYP). The consultants 
will  (i)  undertake  detailed  assessment  of  rural  transport,  in  particular  transport  operators, 
terminals, vehicles, and routes; (ii) identify priority rural transport projects to be implemented 
under the 11th FYP in line with the Government’s objectives; (iii) recommend policy reforms for 
improving  passenger  and  freight  transport  services  to  rural  areas;  and  (iv)  strengthen  the 
Government’s capacity to plan and implement rural transport improvements. 
 
2.  The technical assistance (TA) findings will be based on case studies in three provinces 
selected from the eastern, central, and western regions. The consultants will undertake surveys 
and conduct stakeholder consultations to assess the needs and demand of the rural population 
for road transport services.      
 
3.  The consultants will review the literature and existing documentation on the country’s 
road  transport  generally,  and  rural  transport  in  particular,  and  provide  a  brief  review  and 
analysis of relevant past initiatives and more recent programs. The consultants will also review 
the experience of other countries where improvements in rural transport were successfully 
realized, and draw lessons as appropriate. 
 
B.  Transport Services  
4.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Review and analyze the structure, operations, and management practices of 
road transport in rural areas of the country, focusing in particular on (a) types of 
ownership (state, provincial, local, and private); (b) size of operator; (c) vehicle 
fleet characteristics; (d) areas served (routes); (e) vehicle utilization; and (f) other 
operational performance indicators. Prepare recommendations for improving the 
quality of transport services to rural areas.  
    
(ii)  Review  the  current  regulatory  framework  regarding  licensing  of  operators, 
vehicles,  and  routes,  and  fare  setting,  and  recommend  changes  needed  to 
encourage operators and improve road transport services.  
 
(iii)  Evaluate the present system for establishing road transport tariffs and identify 
improvements for rural areas. This will include assessing the current practice of 
offsetting operational losses in remote areas with profitable long-distance routes 
and urban operations. 
 
(iv)  Assess  the  need  for  targeted  government  subsidies  and  concessions  to 
encourage  operators  to  improve  road  transport  in  rural  areas.  Estimate  the 
nature  and  level  of  such  subsidies  and  concessions,  and  recommend 
implementation measures, including timeframes for withdrawal of subsidies and 
concessions once the objectives are achieved. 
 
(v)  Review the informal transport services operating in remotely located population 
centers and prepare recommendations for improving their quality, safety, tariff-

setting,  and  general  operational  practices.  This  may  include  proposing  a 
regulatory framework for informal transport services.     
 
(vi)  Review  vehicle  inspection  needs  and  prepare  recommendations  relating  to 
passenger and vehicle safety. 
 
(vii)  Review the role of provincial and local road transport administrators in rural 
areas, including the methods used to consult and/or determine public needs, and 
suggest improvements. 
 
(viii)  Assess  the  demand  for  rural  transport  services  by  2010  and  prepare  a 
development plan for extending road transport services to all rural population 
centers that will be connected to the road network under the 11th FYP. 
 
C.  Transport Terminals 
 
5.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Review transport terminals/stations/stops at prefecture, county, township, and 
village  levels,  and  prepare  recommendations  for  improvements  in  transport 
terminals serving rural areas.  
 
(ii)  Review the standard designs, layout, and necessary facilities and equipment for 
transport terminals/stations/stops, and recommend appropriate changes to meet 
the needs of rural areas.  
 
(iii)  Assess the provision of vehicle maintenance facilities at transport terminals and 
prepare recommendations for improvements. Also propose options for provision 
of additional services to improve the financial viability of the terminals.  
 
(iv)  Assess the need for transport terminals by 2010 and prepare a development plan 
and criteria for prioritizing transport terminals in all rural population centers to be 
connected to the road network under the 11th FYP.   
 
D.  Policy Reforms 
 
6.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Review  the  policy  framework  affecting  rural  road  transport,  detailing  the 
legislative and regulatory environment, identifying the responsibilities of different 
government agencies, and assessing how effectively the framework is being 
implemented.  
 
(ii)  Based on the needs identified in section B above, prepare recommendations for 
reforms in the policy framework so as to improve the road transport services in 
rural areas. 
 
E.  Financing 
 
7.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks.

Appendix 3  11 
(i)  Based on the needs identified for development and expansion of rural transport 
services to meet the demand under the 11th FYP, develop criteria for financing 
by the Ministry of Communications (MOC), keeping in view the current practice of 
provision of subsidies by MOC. 
   
(ii)  Assess  the  capacity  of  local  governments  to  contribute towards  financing  of 
transport services and terminals in their jurisdictions. 
 
(iii)  Identify the level of financing to be provided by external agencies and the private 
sector. 
 
F.  Workshops 
 
8.  Based on the data collected, information obtained and issues identified, the consultants 
will  conduct  stakeholder  consultation  workshops  in  each  of  the  selected  provinces.  These 
workshops will be held in close cooperation with relevant agencies related to the road transport 
sector. The findings of these workshops will contribute towards preparation of the draft final 
report.   
 
9.  A national consultation workshop participated in by MOC, Ministry of Finance, National 
Development Reform Commission, related provincial agencies, civil society, the private sector, 
and other stakeholders, will be held to disseminate the findings contained in the draft final 
report, and to seek guidance on finalizing the report. In close collaboration with MOC, Ministry of 
Finance, and National Development Reform Commission, the consultants will prepare an issues 
and options paper to facilitate discussions and reaching a common understanding.    
 
G.  Capacity Development/Training  
 
10.  The consultants will (i) undertake assessment of capacity development needs of MOC 
and other provincial and local level agencies responsible for road transport in rural areas, and 
(ii) identify and develop appropriate training programs to improve their performance.  
 
11.  The consultants will identify, for MOC, overseas training opportunities aimed at capacity 
development of senior management in improving planning, financing, and operations of rural 
road transport services, and make logistical arrangements for government officials nominated to 
participate in overseas training.
